statement.text: Carotid shunting provides cerebral blood flow during CEA clamp time, with use guided by selective, routine, or never philosophies based on monitoring and surgeon experience.
statement.formal: Approaches: Routine shunting, selective shunting (based on monitoring), or never shunting; Monitoring: EEG, stump pressure, TCD, awake testing; No consensus: Similar outcomes across approaches

explanation.intuition: When we clamp the carotid artery during surgery, blood flow to the brain temporarily stops on that side. A shunt is a temporary bypass tube that keeps blood flowing while we work on the artery.
explanation.key_insight: There is no clear evidence that one shunting strategy is superior - routine, selective, or never shunting all produce acceptable results in experienced hands.
explanation.technical_details: Carotid shunting involves placing a temporary conduit (Javid, Pruitt-Inahara, Sundt, or other) to maintain cerebral perfusion during the endarterectomy. Three philosophies exist: (1) Routine shunting - all patients, (2) Selective shunting - based on monitoring (EEG, stump pressure, TCD, or awake testing), (3) Never shunting - expeditious surgery without shunt. Each approach has proponents, and no randomized trial demonstrates clear superiority. Most surgeons use selective shunting based on monitoring.
common_misconceptions: Shunting is always necessary - FALSE, many patients tolerate clamping
Shunting eliminates stroke risk - FALSE, shunts can cause embolization or intimal injury
Contralateral occlusion mandates shunting - FALSE, may tolerate clamping with good collaterals
EEG monitoring is 100% reliable - FALSE, has limitations

routine_shunting.rationale: Maximizes cerebral protection for all patients

selective_shunting.rationale: Shunt only those who demonstrate cerebral ischemia

stump_pressure.technique: Measure ICA pressure with CCA clamped

awake_testing.technique: Regional anesthesia, test neurologic function with clamping

javid.design: Internal shunt with T-tube for flushing

pruitt_inahara.advantages: Balloon holds position, less blood loss

evidence.cochrane_review: No clear evidence of benefit for routine vs selective shunting

definition.@value: Use of temporary conduits to maintain cerebral perfusion during carotid endarterectomy clamp time.

treatment: Selective, routine, or never shunting based on surgeon preference

learning_objectives: Compare routine, selective, and never shunting philosophies
Describe monitoring methods for selective shunting
Identify shunt-related complications and prevention strategies
clinical_pearls: No RCT proves one shunting strategy is superior - surgeon experience matters
Stump pressure <40-50 mmHg suggests need for shunting
Shunts can cause complications - don't shunt unnecessarily
Contralateral occlusion doesn't mandate shunting - monitor and decide
Expeditious surgery (<20-25 min clamp time) may avoid shunting need
